definition: The price at which you can buy a currency pair. Also called the offer price. Always higher than the bid price.
Average True Range - an indicator measuring market volatility by calculating average price range over a period.
The first currency in a currency pair. In EUR/USD, EUR is the base currency.
A market characterized by falling prices and pessimistic sentiment.
Expecting prices to fall. A bearish trader anticipates downward movement.
The price at which you can sell a currency pair. Always lower than the ask price.
A volatility indicator consisting of a moving average with upper and lower bands based on standard deviations.
When price moves above resistance or below support, potentially starting a new trend.
A firm or individual that executes buy and sell orders on behalf of traders.
A market characterized by rising prices and optimistic sentiment.
Expecting prices to rise. A bullish trader anticipates upward movement.
Slang term for the GBP/USD currency pair, referring to the transatlantic telegraph cable.
A chart type showing open, high, low, and close prices with a body and wicks.
Borrowing a low-interest currency to buy a high-interest currency to profit from the rate differential.
National institution controlling monetary policy, like the Federal Reserve or European Central Bank.
A period when price moves sideways within a range, showing market indecision.
Consumer Price Index - measures inflation by tracking price changes in consumer goods and services.
A currency pair that doesn't include the US Dollar, like EUR/GBP or AUD/JPY.
Opening and closing all positions within the same trading day, not holding overnight.
A practice account with virtual money for testing strategies without real risk.
When price and an indicator move in opposite directions, potentially signaling a reversal.
A candlestick with nearly equal open and close, showing market indecision.
Central bank policy focused on growth and employment, typically involving low rates or stimulus.
The decline from a peak to a trough in account equity, measured as a percentage.
Electronic Communication Network - provides direct market access without a dealing desk.
Exponential Moving Average - gives more weight to recent prices, making it more responsive than SMA.
Your account balance plus or minus any unrealized profit or loss from open positions.
A currency pair combining a major currency with an emerging market currency, like USD/TRY.
Tool identifying potential support/resistance levels based on Fibonacci ratios (38.2%, 50%, 61.8%).
The execution of an order at a specific price.
Having no open positions. Also called being square.
Foreign Exchange - the global market for trading currencies, operating 24/5.
Central bank communication about future monetary policy intentions.
Analyzing economic factors, news, and events to predict currency movements.
A price level that wasn't traded, appearing as a space on charts, often after weekends or news.
Gross Domestic Product - measures total economic output of a country.
Buying a currency pair with expectation of price increase.
Selling a currency pair with expectation of price decrease.
When the 50-period MA crosses above the 200-period MA, signaling potential bullish trend.
Bullish reversal candlestick with long lower wick and small body near the top.
Central bank policy focused on fighting inflation, typically involving rate hikes.
Taking a position to offset risk in another position.
The market where banks trade currencies with each other, forming the basis of forex pricing.
The cost of borrowing money, set by central banks, heavily influencing currency values.
Occurring within a single trading day.
The ability to control large positions with small capital, expressed as a ratio like 100:1.
An order to buy below current price or sell above current price at a specified level.
The ease of buying/selling an asset without significantly affecting its price.
A trade where you've bought a currency pair, profiting from price increases.
A standardized unit of currency. Standard lot = 100,000 units, mini = 10,000, micro = 1,000.
Moving Average Convergence Divergence - momentum indicator showing relationship between two MAs.
The most traded currency pairs, all including USD: EUR/USD, GBP/USD, USD/JPY, USD/CHF.
The amount of capital required to open and maintain a leveraged position.
When account equity falls below required margin, broker may close positions.
An order to buy or sell immediately at the current market price.
An indicator that smooths price data by calculating average price over a specific period.
Non-Farm Payrolls - monthly US employment report, highly market-moving for USD.
An instruction to execute a trade at specified conditions.
A trade held past the daily market close, subject to swap/rollover charges.
Market condition where price has risen sharply and may be due for a pullback. RSI above 70.
Market condition where price has fallen sharply and may be due for a bounce. RSI below 30.
An order that executes automatically when price reaches a specified level.
Percentage in Point - the smallest price movement, typically 0.0001 for most pairs, 0.01 for JPY.
A technical level calculated from previous period's high, low, close, used for support/resistance.
Purchasing Managers' Index - measures manufacturing and services sector health.
An open trade that will profit or lose as the market moves.
Calculating the appropriate lot size based on risk tolerance and stop loss distance.
Trading based on raw price movement and patterns rather than indicators.
A predetermined price level where you'll close a trade to take profits.
Quantitative Easing - central bank buying assets to inject money and stimulate economy.
The second currency in a pair. In EUR/USD, USD is the quote currency.
A sustained increase in price.
A market moving sideways between support and resistance without clear trend.
A price level where selling pressure prevents further upward movement.
A temporary price reversal within a larger trend.
A change in price direction from uptrend to downtrend or vice versa.
Strategies to limit losses and protect capital, including position sizing and stop losses.
Market sentiment where investors flee to safe havens due to fear or uncertainty.
Market sentiment where investors seek higher returns in riskier assets.
The ratio of potential profit to potential loss in a trade, like 1:2 or 1:3.
Interest paid or earned for holding a position overnight, based on rate differential.
Relative Strength Index - oscillator measuring momentum, ranging from 0 to 100.
Currencies that strengthen during uncertainty: USD, JPY, CHF.
A strategy making many small profits from tiny price movements, holding for seconds/minutes.
A major trading period: Asian (Tokyo), European (London), or American (New York).
A trade where you've sold a currency pair, profiting from price decreases.
The difference between expected and actual execution price, common during volatility.
Simple Moving Average - calculates average price giving equal weight to all periods.
The difference between bid and ask price, representing broker's profit.
A predetermined level to exit a losing trade, limiting potential loss.
An order to buy above current price or sell below current price, used for breakouts.
A price level where buying interest prevents further downward movement.
Interest paid or earned for holding overnight positions. Same as rollover.
Holding positions for days to weeks to capture larger price moves.
An order that automatically closes your position at a predetermined profit level.
Analyzing historical price patterns and indicators to forecast future movements.
A single price movement, either up or down.
A stop loss that moves automatically as price moves in your favor, locking in profit.
The general direction of price movement: uptrend, downtrend, or sideways.
A line connecting swing highs or lows to visualize trend direction.
The degree of price fluctuation. High volatility means large swings, low means stable.
The number of contracts or lots traded during a period.
When price makes sharp movements in both directions, triggering stops before resuming trend.
The thin lines above and below a candlestick body, showing high and low prices.
A period where large traders are buying, typically at support, before an uptrend.
Simultaneously buying and selling to profit from price differences in different markets.
Chart type showing open, high, low, close with vertical bars and horizontal ticks.
One hundredth of a percentage point (0.01%). Used for interest rate changes.
A two-candle reversal pattern where bearish candle completely engulfs previous bullish candle.
The difference between highest buying price and lowest selling price.
When a trade's current price equals entry price, resulting in zero profit or loss.
A two-candle reversal pattern where bullish candle completely engulfs previous bearish candle.
An order to buy at a specified price below current market, anticipating a pullback.
An order to buy at a specified price above current market, anticipating a breakout.
Parallel trendlines containing price movement, with support below and resistance above.
A market with irregular price movements lacking clear direction.
The final price of a trading period, or the act of exiting a position.
A fee charged by brokers for executing trades, separate from the spread.
Statistical relationship between two currency pairs. Can be positive or negative.
Another term for the quote currency in a currency pair.
Two currencies traded against each other, like EUR/USD or GBP/JPY.
When 50-period MA crosses below 200-period MA, signaling potential bearish trend.
A broker model where the broker acts as market maker and may trade against clients.
A period where large traders are selling, typically at resistance, before a downtrend.
Bullish reversal pattern with two lows at similar levels, signaling upward movement.
Bearish reversal pattern with two peaks at similar levels, signaling downward movement.
A series of lower highs and lower lows, indicating bearish market direction.
The price level at which you enter a trade.
The price level at which you close a trade, either at profit target or stop loss.
Moving average giving more weight to recent prices for faster response to changes.
When price briefly breaks support/resistance but quickly reverses, trapping traders.
Conditions of extreme volatility where prices move rapidly and execution may be delayed.
Federal Reserve - the central bank of the United States.
A continuation pattern resembling a flag, showing brief consolidation before trend resumes.
Unrealized profit or loss on open positions, changing with price movement.
An indicator combining price change and volume to measure buying/selling pressure.
The amount of capital available to open new positions.
